reversi

Class GameState

  • java.lang.Object
    • reversi.GameState

  • public class GameState
extends java.lang.Object
    A class whose instances describe the state of the game (the board configuration). The values in the board array are:
    • -1 - an empty square
    • 0 - Player 0's disc
    • 1 - Player 1's disc
    The origin (coordinates (0,0)) of the board is the upper left corner.

    • Constructor Summary

    • Constructor Detail

      • GameState

        public GameState()
        Creates a new board of size of 8x8

      • GameState

        public GameState(int size)
        Creates a new instance with board size of size*size. Initially, there are always four discs in the middle of the board.
        Parameters:
        size - Size of the board

      • GameState

        public GameState(GameState other)
        Creates a copy of another instance of the GameState class.
        Parameters:
        other - The game state to be copied

    • Method Detail

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Clears the board and sets the four beginning discs on it.

      • getWidth

        public int getWidth()
        Returns the width of the board

      • getHeight

        public int getHeight()
        Returns the height of the board

      • getMarkAt

        public int getMarkAt(int x,
            int y)
        Returns the player index of the disc in coordinates (x,y). The caller must take care that the coordinates are legal.
        Parameters:
        x - x coordinate
        y - y coordinate
        Returns:
        0 = Player 0's disc, 1 = Player 1's disc, -1 = an empty square

      • addMove

        public boolean addMove(Move move)
        Registers a move. If you want to avoid creating a new instance of the Move class, you can use the setMarkAt() method.
        Parameters:
        move - an object describing the move
        Returns:
        false, if the move is illegal, otherwise true.
        See Also:
        setMarkAt(int,int,int)

      • setMarkAt

        public boolean setMarkAt(int x,
                int y,
                int value)
        Places a disc in the coordinates (x,y). When a new disc is placed on the board, all other discs are automatically updated. If the move is illegal, the game state is not updated.
        Parameters:
        x - x coordinate
        y - y coordinate
        value - Player index of the disc that is placed on the board
        Returns:
        false, if the move is illegal, otherwise true

      • getPossibleMoves

        public java.util.Vector getPossibleMoves(int playerIndex)
        Returns all possible moves as Move objects stored into a Vector. If there are no moves the player can make, the length of the vector is 0. An example: 
         Vector moves = state.getPossibleMoves(0); //The possible moves for player 0
 for (int i=0;i<moves.size();i++)
   {
     Move move = (Move)moves.elementAt(i);
     doSomethingWith(move);
   }
        Parameters:
        playerIndex - The player index of the player that is making the move
        Returns:
        The list of possible moves

      • getPossibleMoveCount

        public int getPossibleMoveCount(int playerIndex)
        Returns the number of possible moves. If the result is zero, there are no moves the player can make and the opponent gets the turn.
        Parameters:
        playerIndex - The player index of the player that is making the move
        Returns:
        The number of possible moves

      • isPossibleMove

        public boolean isPossibleMove(int x,
                     int y,
                     int playerIndex)
        Checks whether a given move is legal. The caller must take care that the coordinates are legal (i.e. inside the board area)
        Parameters:
        x - x coordinate
        y - y coordinate
        playerIndex - The player index
        Returns:
        true, if and only if the player can make a move to the given coordinates

      • getMarkCount

        public int getMarkCount(int playerIndex)
        Returns the number of player's discs on the board
        Parameters:
        playerIndex - The player index. If -1, the empty squares are counted.
        Returns:
        The number of player's discs on the board

      • getInterestingArea

        public java.awt.Rectangle getInterestingArea()
        Returns a Rectangle object which contains the region containing all the discs on the board extended with one square to each direction. In the example below, the bounded region would be returned. 
         . . . . . . . . . .
 . +-----------+ . .
 . | . . . . . | . .
 . | . o o o . | . .
 . | . . o o . | . .
 . | . . o o . | . .
 . | . . . . . | . .
 . +-----------+ . .
 . . . . . . . . . .
        Returns:
        Rectangle object. The boundaries of the interesting area is in the variables Rectangle.x, Rectangle.y, Rectangle.width and Rectangle.height.

      • getNewInstance

        public GameState getNewInstance(Move move)
        A.getNewInstance(move) creates a new GameState object by making a copy of A and making the given move to the new object.
        Parameters:
        move - The move to be made. If null, a reference to the original object will be returned.
        Returns:
        new GameState object or null, if the move is invalid

      • getNewInstance

        public GameState getNewInstance(int x,
                       int y,
                       int value)
        A.getNewInstance(x,y,value) creates a new GameState object by making a copy of A and making the given move to the new object.
        Parameters:
        x - x coordinate
        y - y coordinate
        value - player index of the player making the move
        Returns:
        new GameState object or null, if the move is invalid

        Checks if two game states are equal.
        Overrides:

        Parameters:

        Returns:
